passages.text: European Aviation Daily
AF- KLM well- priced debt, TAP Portugal 2Q profit falls, Ryanair lobbying against Spanish charges increase
- Well-priced new debt for AF-KLM- TAP 2Q results see profits fall- Ryanair lobbying against Spanish airport charges increase

Yesterday AF- KLM successfully placed €500 million senior unsecured notes under its EMTN with a 5- years maturity and fixed annual coupon of \(3.75\%\) . We note that this is well- priced debt for AF- KLM and will extend repayment schedules and manage down average rates. The company says the proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes.

We would expect this cash to be well placed to repay the expensive perpetuals and possibly offer the group flexibility for the planned acquisition of the larger stake in SAS. Cash in hand may also be helpful when TAP's privatisation – in which AF- KLM has expressed clear interest – edges forwards.

Yesterday TAP Portugal released 2Q25 results, which saw EBIT fall \(21\%\) to €136m, still a decent \(12\%\) margin. Overall both RASK and yield fell \(3\%\) . By region, PRASK fell \(1\%\) to Latin America, fell \(2\%\) to North America, was flat in Europe and advanced \(10\%\) to Africa, substantially driven by an 8 point advance in load factor \(\Delta 0.78\%\) . The decline to group unit revenues does reflect the faster growth on long haul, which has lower unit revenues.

In terms of costs, ex fterit costs rose \(6\%\) , with the increase in total CASK held to \(1\%\) thanks to falling fuel costs. The cost pressures come from aircraft ownership, labour and ATC fees. The quarter saw a poor operational performance with on- time performance (departures within 15 mins of schedule) falling from \(60\%\) to \(53\%\) , due to ATC, infrastructure problems and weather.

As of 30 June 2025, TAP maintained a strong liquidity balance of EUR1,166.8m, an increase of EUR5.2 million compared to 31 December 2024. The Net Debt/EBITDA ratio improved to 2.2x from 2.4x in the 2024 pro- forma accounts and 2.6x in the 2024 statutory accounts.
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 6. Completed: 29- Aug- 25, 08:46 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 08:50 GMT Restricted - External

The outlook commentary is cautious with stable forward bookings YoY despite capacity increasing \(4\%\) in the summer. Booking windows are becoming shorter. Yields are impacted by competitive pressures. The CEO commentary also flags operational challenges in peak summer, with severe border control challenges in Portugal highlighted as a key problem for operations.

Ryanair continues its lobbying against fees and taxes, with fresh reports across the media (eg Daily Express, 28 August) of its plans to cut flights to and from regional airports in Spain, citing Aena's proposed airport charge increase. Ryanair will announce the reduction next Wednesday. Eddie Wilson, Ryanair DAC CEO, said cuts could leave Spanish regions with "fewer passengers, fewer jobs, fewer connections, and fewer opportunities for tourism". Ryanair is already withdrawing from smaller regional airports where support packages have been withdrawn. In our view, airport charges in Spain are low compared to across Europe. It is no surprise to see Ryanair lobby against airport charges increases, but we think the greater impact on Ryanair's Spanish economics comes from the scale of marketing support and the price of handling by airport.
Ryanair will reveal what airports face the cuts at a press conference in Madrid next week. We would not expect Ryanair to remove services from prime beach airports where peak period slots are scarce.

Aviation24. be reports that Eurowings is expanding its winter schedule to Morocco, offering 16 weekly connections across six European airports. The airline will launch new flights to Marrakesh from Hanover, Salzburg, Stuttgart, and Prague, while increasing Düsseldorf- Marrakesh to three flights per week. In addition, Cologne- Fez (2x weekly) will continue, and Agadir will remain served from Düsseldorf (up to 2x weekly) and Stuttgart (1x weekly). In total, Eurowings will operate 11 flights per week to Marrakesh and 3 to Agadir.

The expansion is consistent with network developments from the pure play LCCs and tour operators who see Morocco's growing popularity as a winter and indeed summer- sun destination, offering better value than Spain.

Aero.de (28 August 2025) reports that in Switzerland, the media see Swiss as suffering an identity crisis, and at Austrian Airlines a union fears for jobs as network planning in the Lufthansa group is to be centralised. Lufthansa has announced plans to exert greater control over its network companies. Lufthansa wants to make decisions about fleets, route networks, ticket prices and sales centrally.

The new Lufthansa organization, also known internally as the "Matrix Next Level", is to take effect in 2026 - and help Lufthansa to higher profits and happier passengers. In Switzerland and Austria, there are reservations about the conversion. The Swiss daily newspaper "Blick" headlined this week: "Lufthansa now wants to Germanize Swiss". In Austria, meanwhile, the Vida trade union fears for the future influence of Austrian Airlines in the Lufthansa Group structure - and for jobs. Vida specifically warns against a further dilution of Austrian flight operations through wet lease agreements. "Intended as an exception, this instrument is now becoming common practice," said Liebhart.

Aero.de (28 August 2025) reports Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary as saying that the airline industry will not achieve the goal of climate- neutral aviation by 2050. Ryanair does not believe that the IATA goal will be secured and expects both the EU SAF targets for 2030 and the industry net zero

target for 2050 to be abandoned. From 2030, the EU will prescribe a SAF content in fuel of at least six percent, of which percent will be e- SAF. Great Britain is setting an even higher target from 2030 with a 9.5 percent SAF quota. IATA has reported that global SAF production volume covers just "0.7 percent of the fuel demand" of global scheduled aviation. Even the small amount would cause 4.4 ton US dollars in additional costs. "The ramp- up of production and efficiency gains to reduce costs must be accelerated," IATA President Willie Walsh demanded.

Telelegrap (28 August) reports that from September 9, 2025, the Lufthansa subsidiary City Airlines will be part of the Star Alliance. The process has taken a year but after an intensive audit, the way is clear for the move into Star. This is strategically relevant as the group needs consumers to see no difference in travelling City Airlines relative to mainline Lufthansa. Until now, however, City Airlines has been flying in Lufthansa livery, but status benefits such as lounge access or priority boarding have not been available for Gold customers of Star Alliance airline programs.

Travel Weekly (Aug 28, 2025) reports that a second Tui Blue hotel in Malaysia is due to open next summer as part of the group's expansion in Asia. The 214- room Tui Blue Medini Johor is expected to start accepting guests in August 2026 under a management agreement as the company sees the country as an emerging holiday destination. The new project follows Tui Blue Haven Ipoh, which opened in September 2024 as the first Tui branded hotel in Malaysia. The second property is located in Medini, a central business district in the Iskandar Puteri area of Johor Bahru. It is close to Legoland Malaysia as well as other family- friendly activities.

Staying in Malaysia, Flight Global (28 August 2025) reports that Malaysia's Capital A aims to divest its aviation business on 11 November, as it enters the "last leg" of the long- drawn out reorganisation process. It expects to gain Thai SEC approval - the remaining regulatory hurdle - in mid- September, before it obtains all remaining consent letters for the divestment.

Capital A is looking to sell its aviation business to sister unit AirAsia X, as part of efforts to restructure its business and exit financially distressed status. The deal - first announced in early 2024 - will eventually see AirAsia and AirAsia X managed under a single entity, with a combined fleet of Airbus A320- family narrowbodies and A330s.

Flight Global (28 August 2025) reports that ALPA, the USA's largest pilot union, has come out strongly against airline trade group IATA's proposal that ICAO increase its recommended pilot retirement age to 67 years. Standards- setting group ICAO's guidelines currently recommend that commercial pilots flying multi- pilot jets be permitted to fly no older than age 65. IATA, which represents airlines from around the world, in recent days petitioned ICAO to raise the limit to 67 years, saying medical studies during the last two decades support the change.

ALPA argues: "The United States is the global leader in aviation safety, and we should resist any attempts to arbitrarily make changes to the regulatory framework that has helped us achieve this record," says ALPA. "The US should continue to provide global leadership on this issue and maintain its current position."

Governments do not necessarily accept ICAO's guidelines. Canada, for instance, sets no retirement age. US Federal Aviation Administration regulations align with ICAO, prohibiting pilots from flying large commercial jets after age 65.
Have a great weekend. Still no new signings ahead of Accrington at home tomorrow. The closure of the transfer window on Monday edges nearer.

Friday, 5 September - Tuesday, 9 September 2025: Corporate Access - Virtual - Back to School with Barclays - European Logistics on 5th- 9th September. We are hosting a series of 40- minute Virtual Fireside Chats with KNIN, DSV, DHL, NTG, HLAG and InPost. Register here
NEW! Tuesday, 9 September 2025: 1500 - 1600 UK: Corporate Access - Virtual - EU SAF policy - Lufthansa head of SAF - All airports are equal. Some are more equal than others. Register here
Monday, 15 September 2025: Corporate Access - EasyJet Frankfurt Roadshow. In- person with Adrian Talbot, Director of Investor Relations.
Wednesday, 17 September 2025: Corporate Access - AdP London Roadshow. 1:1 and group meetings with Deputy CEO and CFO.
NEW Monday 1 December: London Aviation Dinner. Details coming soon.
Tuesday, 10 March 2026: The May Fair - London: Barclays Transport Conference (incl. Business Services, Leisure and Infrastructure). Details coming soon.

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Valuation Methodology: Our airline price targets are defined by a three- stage economic value creation DCF. This model starts with invested capital, then assesses the net present value of the economic value created or destroyed during a five- year explicit forecast period, during a subsequent 20- year value driver period in which we assume EBIT levels and growth rates are held stable, and finally during a three- year fade period in which we assume economic value creation (or destruction) fades to zero. The advantage of our three- stage DCF model is that it takes into account our explicit forecasts for the coming five years, rather than just as single year. The valuation is also explicit about the assumed mid- term profitability of the business. The valuation method does not include a terminal value. Our AF- KLM €10.50 price target is based on a mid- term EBIT margin of \(5.0\%\) and a WACC of \(5.9\%\) .

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Industry factors relating to economic outlook, geopolitics and oil prices could support or weaken the share price. Key company- specific upside risks might arise from a labour productivity deal at KLM. Downside risks could arise from further taxation in France and execution risks from expanding Transavia.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated.
